instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message:
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board / <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. Voltage starts at .75V but drops to .54V after a few seconds on <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>.
Board goes to 20v and drops to 19.95V drawing 1.4A but no USB activity or inclination that it is booting.
Resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> seems low compared to donor board I have: 4.5 ohms compared to 13.5 ohms but donor board quite possibly isn't a good reference.
I cant get it into DFU Mode at all but because of that, I checked AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages and discovered what I think is incorrect with the PPVDDCPU line.

Vcore is at .975V. Thermal cam shows fair amount of heat at PCH. Power rails going show good values though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message: The other AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages have correct value?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message: Yes. Through other suggestion being that I couldn't get DFU, I reflashed T2 Rom by pulling chip and placing back, but logic board behaves still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message:
Check the normal voltage of that rail in other T2 board.
Lift L7806-09 and <RESISTOR>R7806</RESISTOR>; check if no low value remains at <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message:
I don't have one to refer to but it looks like based on other threads it should stay at .75V. PUlling those components prevents the board from starting. It won't draw more than 5V. voltage readings on <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> side that circumstance is .3V. Just to see what would happen, I tried injecting .75V for the awake signal to see what would happen and it seems that it interferes with the commuications because the board just stays at 20V 0 Amps and won't then drop to just under 20V like normal.

With components back on and everything normal, board goes to 20V 0 amps then drops just under 20V and The USB drive light comes on for a few seconds board draws almost 2 amps and USB light shuts off then the board goes back to drawing 20V 0 amps, and lowers to just under 20V one more time draws 80 mA, and then just stays at 20V, 0 amps and doesn't change.

Wondering if the CPU is shorted. This board gets all the way through and sends <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL>. CPU goes to 95 degrees celsius in a few seconds when the voltage drop under 20. The heat sink is off. I know macs run hot but that has to be too hot, too fast, correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No boot, drop in <SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL> voltage
threads.message:
95 degrees in few seconds looks too much.
CPU is susect there...
